bibl.title: Minutes from the annual meeting of the Board of Managers, Walter Reed Memorial Association, November 21, 1951

div1.p: This documents records the deliberations of the Reed Memorial Association. Special attention is paid to the centennial of Reed's birth.

div1.head: Minutes from the annual meeting of the Board of Managers, Walter Reed Memorial Association, November 21, 1951
div1.p:
The next order of business was the election of officers and new members. It was moved
and seconded that the officers for the last year, namely, Col. J. F. Siler, President,
Dr. Philip S. Hench, Vice President, Brig. Gen. Albert G. Love, Secretary, and Mr. Hans W.
Ireland, Treasurer, be reelected for the ensuing year. The chairman asked if any member
desired to make any other nominations. None were made. He then requested Gen. Keefer to
take the chair. The motion to reelect the present officers was carried unanimously.

The chairman called attention to the fact that 1951 is the 100th anniversary of the
birth of Walter Reed. He stated that he wished to express his own appreciation, in which
he was sure all of the members of the Board concurred, of the splendid publicity work done
by the staff of the Army Medical Center in the dissemination of information during the year
in the press and in local meetings in regard to the life and work of Walter Reed.

The 13th of September, 1951, the 100th anniversary of the birth of Walter Reed, was
proclaimed “Walter Reed Day” by the Commissioners of the District of Columbia and by the
Board of Supervisors of Gloucester, Va., near his birthplace at Belvoir, Va. The Governor
of Virginia issued a proclamation for further observances throughout the State. Special
Commemorative services were held at his birthplace, Belvoir, Va., where Gen. Earle Standlee
spoke in lieu of Gen. Paul H. Streit who was unable to attend. Col. Joseph A. Weaver spoke
at similar services at Harrisonburg, Va., Walter Reed's second home. There were special
exhibits in the Army Medical Museum and at the College of Medicine, New York University,
Major Reed's second medical school. There were appropriate services also at the Walter Reed
Army Medical Center, including a radio program. Miss Lena Townshend, now 76, of Baltimore,
Md., who was associated with the yellow fever experimental work as a nurse, was present and
participated. Major Reed's daughter, Blossom Reed, was guest of honor at Gloucester, Va.,
and placed a wreath in honor of her father. Gen. Walter Reed, son of Major Reed, participated
in the services at the Army Medical Center. In addition, the Army Medical Center was re-
designated the Walter Reed Army Medical Center by General Order No. 80, Department of the
Army, Washington, 13 September 1951.

General Love stated that, since he had assumed the duties of Secretary of the Association,
he found by looking through the records of the Association that Colonel Siler, while Secretary,
had done a splendid job in recording, reworking and assembling the various important documents
associated with the proceedings of the Association during its history of almost fifty years.
He expressed the opinion that the Association was under great obligations to Colonel Siler for
his fine work. His remarks received the enthusiastic approval of all present although no vote
was requested.

Colonel Siler spoke of the special exhibit of Walter Reed material at the Medical
Museum and asked that consideration be given to a suitable depository of such material. Dr.
Fred L. Soper and Gen. F. R. Keefer both express the opinion that, should a permanent exhibit
be arranged, suitable provisions should be made for material showing Dr. Carlos Finlay's very
important work leading up to Major Reed's final experimental work.

Doctor Soper spoke of the Certificate and $500.00 award to Mr. J. A. Le Prince by the
National Malaria Society at its recent meeting in Chicago, I11., for his outstanding contri-
bution to the prevention of malarial infections and for his other work in tropical medicine.
Mr. Le Prince is well known to all those interested in tropical medicine for his splendid
work in association with Gen. William Crawford Gorgas in Havana and Panama. The address of
Mr. J. A. Le Prince is 929 Oakmont Street, Memphis Tenn. Dr. Soper stated that Mr. Le Prince
spoke of the interest of Mr. Guss Lambert in the Walter Reed experimental work in Cuba.
Mr. Lambert has material that may be of interest for a museum exhibit.

There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned to meet at the call of the
President.
